Address: 1 Epping Road, North Ryde, NSW, Australia
Why: Australia taxes business profits on companies with "permanent establishment" in the country. Because the vast majority of Microsoft sales are handled by a Singapore entity, they are not taxed in Australia.
Notes: Microsoft sold about $2.1 billion worth of goods to Australian customers in its 2014 fiscal year, but only $100 million of that was recorded for tax purposes in Australia. The rest was booked by a Singapore sales unit.
calculation notes: Is assuming Singapore / Aus estimated revenue from Sample hearing wasn't passed up the chain, and profit accrued at the rough corporate rate. (Also estimated Irish tax based on the UK subsidiary ratio)

Notes: When Microsoft sold licenses to resell its software to this Singapore subsidiary in 2004, the deal projected the region's sales would be flat in the years ahead, an IRS audit found. Instead, the East Asian economies the Singapore unit sold to -- which were already booming at the time of the deal -- grew rapidly during the following decade.

Address: 1 Marina Boulevard, #22-01 One Marina Boulevard, Singapore
Why: Microsoft Operations licenses, but doesn't own, the rights to sell Microsoft software. That means it sends much of the money it makes, before taxes, to the Bermuda company it licenses the software from.
Notes: Microsoft Operations Singapore makes physical and digital copies of the company's software, and licenses them down the line to the company's sales force.
calculation notes: Source is Senate report, effective rate in 2011.

Address: Clarendon House, 2 Church Street, Hamilton, HM 11, Bermuda
Why: Bermuda doesn't levy taxes on corporations.
Notes: MAIL, which has no employees, exists only to acquire the rights to Microsoft software from the parent company and resell them to the Singapore entity.
calculation notes: Source is Senate report, effective rate in 2011.

Why: Nevada has no state corporate income tax. Through an arrangement in which Microsoft's Puerto Rico unit funds some company research, 46 percent of each U.S. sale goes directly to Puerto Rico without triggering U.S. federal income tax.
Notes: Microsoft started its Nevada licensing outpost in 1997, part of a decadelong spree in which the company seeded 57 subsidiaries in the state. The end result means that much of Microsoft's sales and investment income avoided Washington state taxes.
calculation notes: Charges full U.S. rate to 53% of the gross. Assumes 47% to PR.

Why: Microsoft negotiated an agreement with Puerto Rican regulators to pay a 2% income tax.
Notes: Microsoft started a Puerto Rico software manufacturing subsidiary in 1989 to take advantage of a tax credit Congress enacted to spur development in U.S. territories. When the credit expired, Microsoft created a new Puerto Rican subsidiary: Microsoft Operations Puerto Rico. In exchange for an initial license payment to Microsoft, MOPR and its corporate parents would own licenses to profit from all Microsoft products -- except Windows -- in the Western Hemisphere.
calculation notes: Source is Senate report, effective rate in 2011.

Why: Bermuda doesn't levy taxes on corporations.
Notes: "This structure is not designed to satisfy any specific manufacturing or business need; rather, it is designed to minimize tax on sales of products sold in the United States." - A 2012 report by the U.S. Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

Address: Matheson, 70 Sir John Rogerson's Quay, Dublin 2, Ireland
Why: Though located in Ireland, Round Island One is headquartered, for tax purposes in Bermuda, allowing its profit to pass tax free to its parent company.
Notes: Round Island One is the Irish hub that funnels Microsoft's retails sales from Europe and the Americas to Bermuda. The company is also the corporate parent of Microsoft's Irish finance units, which invest a portion of Microsoft's offshore cash.

Address: Thames Valley Park, Reading, Berkshire, UK
Why: Most sales to U.K. customers are treated as Irish income -- and untaxed in the U.K. -- because Microsoft's Irish sales subsidiary has no "permanent establishment" in the country.
Notes: Microsoft's U.K. and Irish units had sales of $3.8 billion in the U.K. during the company's 2014 fiscal year. Because most of that revenue was passed on to Bermuda, Ireland and Luxembourg, Microsoft's U.K. marketing subsidiary paid about $16 million in taxes.
calculation notes: Gets to 7% if you EXCLUDE sales MIOL books outside of the country.

Address: Atrium Building Block D, Carmenhall Road, Sandyford Industrial Estate, Dublin 18, Ireland
Why: Ireland generally taxes companies on the income attributable to their Irish branch. Most of the sales the Irish unit collects are from the rest of Europe, and are passed on in the form of tax-deductible royalty payments to the corporate parent.
Notes: Microsoft Ireland Operations employs 735 people, and during the 2014 fiscal year earned $1.2 million in profit per employee. The companywide average was $172,000 per employee.
calculation notes: 2.8% is assuming all of the turnover on MIOL's 2014 return was sourced to Ireland and taxed there, instead of up the chain in revenue payments. Senate report pegged effective rate at 7.3%.
